18.text: The  Yandal  Belt  contains  some  of  Australia’s  largest  gold  mines  that  have produced

19.text: over 6Moz Au since the mid 1990s.  These include major mines at Jundee, Darlot and

20.text: Bronzewing  -  Mount  McClure.  Jundee  produced  its  three  millionth  ounce  of  gold  in

21.text: 2004.    In  2004,  the  Darlot  operations  produced  146Koz  Au  @  5.3g/t  Au.  The

22.text: Bronzewing - Mount McClure Mine, last active in 2004 and presently the subject of a

23.text: mining  feasibility  study,  typically  produced  220-270Koz  Au  per  annum  at  a  grade  of

24.text: around 4.6g/t Au. The Yandal Belt also contains a number of very significant historical

25.text: mining  areas  and  defined  gold  deposits  that  are  the  subject  of  ongoing  exploration

text:
The  Yandal  Belt  contains  some  of  Australia’s  largest  gold  mines  that  have produced 
 over 6Moz Au since the mid 1990s.  These include major mines at Jundee, Darlot and 
 Bronzewing  -  Mount  McClure.  Jundee  produced  its  three  millionth  ounce  of  gold  in 
 2004.    In  2004,  the  Darlot  operations  produced  146Koz  Au  @  5.3g/t  Au.  The 
 Bronzewing - Mount McClure Mine, last active in 2004 and presently the subject of a 
 mining  feasibility  study,  typically  produced  220-270Koz  Au  per  annum  at  a  grade  of 
 around 4.6g/t Au. The Yandal Belt also contains a number of very significant historical 
 mining  areas  and  defined  gold  deposits  that  are  the  subject  of  ongoing  exploration

23.text: The Belt has a  semi-arid to arid climate, with hot summers and cool to mild winters.

24.text: The  mean  annual  rainfall  of  200mm  falls  predominantly  in  the  summer.  The  area  is

25.text: subject to both droughts and short-term floods after thunderstorms. Cyclonic rain may

26.text: cause the salt lakes to become inundated with water for extensive periods, however,

salt beds surrounded by sand and gypsum kopi dunes (Figure 3).  
 The Belt has a  semi-arid to arid climate, with hot summers and cool to mild winters.  
 The  mean  annual  rainfall  of  200mm  falls  predominantly  in  the  summer.  The  area  is 
 subject to both droughts and short-term floods after thunderstorms. Cyclonic rain may 
 cause the salt lakes to become inundated with water for extensive periods, however, 
 Lake  Maitland  does  not  normally  contain  large  bodies  of  water.  Nonetheless,  areas 
 within and adjacent to the salt lake may become impassable for weeks to months after 
 The vegetation cover on E37/822 is dominated by Acacia and Eucalyptus shrubs and 
 trees. Lake Maitland itself has sparse cover of Samphire, Spinifex, Bluebush, saltbush 
 and Dunna-dunna vegetation. 
 E37/822  was  granted  for  a  period  of  5  years  commencing  5  April  2006,  and  covers 
 portions of 12 blocks as follows: 
 Wiluna 2750 o,t,y                                                                                                          
 The tenement covers an area approximately 16km long by 3km wide in the south and 
 1.6km wide in the north. The Tenement is 100% owned by Echo. 
 The  primary  exploration  target  is  hydrothermal  gold  mineralisation.  However,  the 
 Project  also  contains  significant  potential  for  near-surface  uranium  mineralisation 
 associated with sediments within the Lake Maitland system.

36.text: The Maitland Project area is mostly devoid of outcropping basement rocks because of

37.text: extensive  Cainozoic  alluvial  and  colluvial  cover  deposits.  The  central  portions  of  the

38.text: Project  area  are  dominated  by  the  Lake  Maitland  playa  lake  system,  which  is

39.text: characterised by extensive deposits of evaporitic and alluvial sediments of Tertiary to

40.text: Recent age. The Lake Maitland salt lake system flows southeast on to Echo’s ground.

text:
The Maitland Project area is mostly devoid of outcropping basement rocks because of 
 extensive  Cainozoic  alluvial  and  colluvial  cover  deposits.  The  central  portions  of  the 
 Project  area  are  dominated  by  the  Lake  Maitland  playa  lake  system,  which  is 
 characterised by extensive deposits of evaporitic and alluvial sediments of Tertiary to 
 Recent age. The Lake Maitland salt lake system flows southeast on to Echo’s ground.  
 The  Lake  Maitland  uranium  deposit  (controlled  by  Redport  Limited,  now  a  wholly 
 owned  subsidiary  of  TSX-listed  Mega  Uranium  Ltd)  is  characterised  as  a  calcrete 
 deposit  containing  carnotite  mineralisation  developed  as  a  single  layer  at  a  depth  of 
 about 1-6m from surface (Figures 4 and 5). The mineralised zone is 1-3m thick, 5km in 
 length (north-south), and up to 2km wide (east-west).  
 In June 2006, Redport reported that Lake Maitland contains a JORC-compliant Inferred 
 Resource, at a 100 ppm U3O8 cut-off, of approximately 32.7 million tonnes @ 0.033% 
 U3O8 (10,747 tonnes U3O8, or 23.7 million pounds U3O8). At a 500ppm U3O8 cut-off, the 
 Inferred Resource is approximately 5.5 million tonnes @ 0.086% U3O8 (4,759 tonnes

19.text: northwest, but is also traversed by narrower, less extensive cross faults trending mainly

20.text: between  north  and  east.    The  shear  zones  and  faults  appear  to  have  played  an

21.text: important  role  in  the  localisation  of  gold  mineralisation.  The  Maitland  tenement

22.text: straddles the major Celia Shear Zone and several cross faults (Figure 2).

24.text: In the gold deposits of the Yandal Belt, the mineralisation is typically closely associated

25.text: with quartz and quartz-carbonate veins.  Many of the gold deposits are associated with

26.text: domains of hydrothermal alteration that formed during the gold mineralisation process.

27.text: The  hydrothermally  altered  rocks  contain  variable  amounts  of  chlorite,  muscovite,

28.text: biotite,  carbonate,  pyrite,  arsenopyrite  and  pyrrhotite.    Proterozoic  dolerite  dykes  cut

29.text: the greenstones, granitoids and the gold mineralised domains.

31.text: Weathering  has  affected  all  rocks  across  the  Yandal  Belt  and  has  resulted  in  the

32.text: formation  of  lateritic  weathering  profiles  that  may  extend  to  150m  depth.    The

33.text: weathered rocks are variably covered by transported overburden which made historical

text:
northwest, but is also traversed by narrower, less extensive cross faults trending mainly 
 between  north  and  east.    The  shear  zones  and  faults  appear  to  have  played  an 
 important  role  in  the  localisation  of  gold  mineralisation.  The  Maitland  tenement 
 straddles the major Celia Shear Zone and several cross faults (Figure 2). 
 In the gold deposits of the Yandal Belt, the mineralisation is typically closely associated 
 with quartz and quartz-carbonate veins.  Many of the gold deposits are associated with 
 domains of hydrothermal alteration that formed during the gold mineralisation process.  
 The  hydrothermally  altered  rocks  contain  variable  amounts  of  chlorite,  muscovite, 
 biotite,  carbonate,  pyrite,  arsenopyrite  and  pyrrhotite.    Proterozoic  dolerite  dykes  cut 
 the greenstones, granitoids and the gold mineralised domains.

 formation  of  lateritic  weathering  profiles  that  may  extend  to  150m  depth.    The 
 weathered rocks are variably covered by transported overburden which made historical

21.text: In 1987, work south of Mount McClure led to the discovery of the Success, Parmelia,

22.text: Challenger and Dragon deposits, followed some two years later by the larger Cockburn

23.text: and Lotus deposits. Drill testing of soil gold geochemical anomalies led to the discovery

24.text: of near-surface gold mineralisation around Jundee between 1989-1992.  Further drilling

25.text: at Jundee since then has defined a number of deeper high-grade gold lodes extending

26.text: to depths exceeding 500m, including the Barton Deeps and West Side lodes.  In 1992,

27.text: shallow  RAB  drilling  beneath  the  margins  of  a  palaeochannel  to  the  east  of  Mount

28.text: McClure resulted in the discovery of the Bronzewing gold deposits.  Four years later, in

29.text: 1996, the Centenary lodes were discovered at a depth of 350m at Darlot.  Exploration

30.text: since the 1980’s has also delineated a number of smaller gold deposits and prospects.

32.text: In  the  late  1960s  to  mid  1970s,  portions  of  the  Yandal  Belt  were  explored  for  nickel

33.text: sulphide  deposits  by  a  number  of  exploration  companies.  Work  included  geological

34.text: mapping,  soil  and  lag  sampling,  ground  magnetic,  induced  polarisation  surveys,  and

35.text: limited RAB, PER and DC drilling.

37.text: The  discovery  of  uranium  mineralisation  within  Lake  Maitland  was  made  in  the  late

38.text: 1960s,  following  a  regional  aerial  radiometric  survey  by  the  BMR  which  identified  a

39.text: large uranium anomaly. Subsequent exploration programs have included more detailed

40.text: radiometric surveys, geological mapping, auger, RAB and aircore drilling.

44.text: The Project area has received minimal exploration efforts over the years probably due

45.text: to the salt lake environment causing problems for the early explorers. Furthermore, the

46.text: external granitoid suite which underlies much of the tenement area has never been a

47.text: high  priority  target  for  gold  or  nickel  exploration  which  have  been  the  dominant

48.text: commodities previously and currently explored for in the Yandal belt.

49.text: Open file searches on previous exploration within the area of E37/822 indicate Swiss

50.text: Aluminium  Mining  in  1970-1971  conducted  Cu  and  Ni  exploration  consisting  of  rock

51.text: chip sampling, percussion drilling and petrography. However this was done on adjacent

52.text: tenements at their Salt Well project (Hays, 1971: report number A2732).

text:
In 1987, work south of Mount McClure led to the discovery of the Success, Parmelia, 
 Challenger and Dragon deposits, followed some two years later by the larger Cockburn 
 and Lotus deposits. Drill testing of soil gold geochemical anomalies led to the discovery 
 of near-surface gold mineralisation around Jundee between 1989-1992.  Further drilling 
 at Jundee since then has defined a number of deeper high-grade gold lodes extending 
 to depths exceeding 500m, including the Barton Deeps and West Side lodes.  In 1992, 
 shallow  RAB  drilling  beneath  the  margins  of  a  palaeochannel  to  the  east  of  Mount 
 McClure resulted in the discovery of the Bronzewing gold deposits.  Four years later, in 
 1996, the Centenary lodes were discovered at a depth of 350m at Darlot.  Exploration 
 since the 1980’s has also delineated a number of smaller gold deposits and prospects.   
 In  the  late  1960s  to  mid  1970s,  portions  of  the  Yandal  Belt  were  explored  for  nickel 
 sulphide  deposits  by  a  number  of  exploration  companies.  Work  included  geological 
 mapping,  soil  and  lag  sampling,  ground  magnetic,  induced  polarisation  surveys,  and 
 limited RAB, PER and DC drilling.    
 The  discovery  of  uranium  mineralisation  within  Lake  Maitland  was  made  in  the  late 
 1960s,  following  a  regional  aerial  radiometric  survey  by  the  BMR  which  identified  a 
 large uranium anomaly. Subsequent exploration programs have included more detailed 
 radiometric surveys, geological mapping, auger, RAB and aircore drilling. 
 HISTORIC EXPLORATION ACTIVTIES ON E37/822. 
 The Project area has received minimal exploration efforts over the years probably due 
 to the salt lake environment causing problems for the early explorers. Furthermore, the 
 external granitoid suite which underlies much of the tenement area has never been a 
 high  priority  target  for  gold  or  nickel  exploration  which  have  been  the  dominant 
 commodities previously and currently explored for in the Yandal belt. 
 Open file searches on previous exploration within the area of E37/822 indicate Swiss 
 Aluminium  Mining  in  1970-1971  conducted  Cu  and  Ni  exploration  consisting  of  rock 
 chip sampling, percussion drilling and petrography. However this was done on adjacent 
 tenements at their Salt Well project (Hays, 1971: report number A2732).

 EXPLORATION DURING THE CURRENT TERM 
 Echo conducted reconnaissance field checking on portions of E37/822. 
 8.2  Recovery of historical information and verification 
 Historical  exploration  information  pertaining  to  the  area  within  and  adjacent  to 
 E37/822 was recovered from a variety of sources, and reviewed.  
 Data  for  the  Sir  Samuel  airborne  magnetic/radiometric  survey  and  the  regional 
 gravity  survey  provided  by  Geoscience  Australia  (Australian  National  Gravity 
 Database v2001) was also recovered.  
 8.3  Re-processing of airborne geophysics 
 The  airborne  magnetic,  radiometric  and  elevation  survey  data  were  processed  to 
 provide coverage over the Project area (Figure 7, 8 and 9). 
 8.4  Preparation of electronic databases 
 ArcView  /  Mapinfo  format  GIS  electronic  geological  databases  have  been 
 established over E37/822 and adjoining areas. These databases include:

42.text: The preparation of electronic databases is ongoing, and expected to be completed

text:
•  topographical, physiographical and geological features 
 •  surface geochemistry and hydro-geochemistry datasets. 
 The preparation of electronic databases is ongoing, and expected to be completed 
 during the next reporting period.
